newsitem.title: INDONESIA: Indonesia's Suharto hopes for peaceful election.
newsitem.headline: Indonesia's Suharto hopes for peaceful election.

text.p: Indonesian President Suharto has called for peaceful general elections next year that would strengthen national unity rather than bruise society, the official Antara news agency said on Monday.

"We hope that the election would not leave bruises in the heart of any group of people or any layer of society," Suharto, who is also chairman of the board of patrons of the ruling Golkar party, said on Sunday night.
Speaking at Golkar's 32nd anniversary celebrations, Suharto said the elections should be competitive as it was natural for contestants to try and get as many votes as possible.
"But competition has to be carried out within the corridor of political ethics and regulations," Suharto said.

Besides Golkar, Indonesia's tightly-controlled electoral system allows only the Moslem-orientated United Development Party (PPP) and the Christian-Nationalist Indonesian Democratic Party (PDI) to contest elections.

The polls, which will send 425 people to fill the elective seats in the 500-member parliament or DPR, are due to be held in late May next year. The remaining 75 seats will be filled by appointed members of the military.
Indonesia's best-known opposition figure, Megawati Sukarnoputri, will not be contesting the elections.

The daughter of late founding president Sukarno, she was ousted from the leadership of the PDI by a government-backed faction in what political analysts have said was a move to sideline her before she could cut into Golkar's vote.
The organisation which oversees the election has refused to accept her list of candidates although Megawati has filed a lawsuit seeking redress.
Golkar Chairman Harmoko, who is also information minister, told the celebration that the party had set a target of 70.02 percent of the vote for the poll.

Golkar has won all five elections held during the 30-year period under Suharto's rule, known as the New Order administration. In 1992, it took 68 percent of the vote, from the 73 percent it won at the 1987 poll.

The general election will be followed by the March 1998 presidential poll when the 1,000-member People's Consultative Assembly (MPR), made up of the DPR and 500 presidential appointees, is expected to elect Suharto for a seventh five-year term.
Golkar stopped short of nominating Suharto during its recent annual conference although it has strongly suggested he is best qualified for the job.
The Merdeka newspaper on Monday listed the nine qualities of the next president as stated by Golkar.

It said the president should be someone who is patriotic and believes in God, has vision and an ability to unite the nation. The person should be a statesman and wise as well as brave enough to make difficult decisions, it said.

The newspaper reported that any candidate should also have a proven record and be acceptable to the people. The next president should be a leader who has consistently implemented the programmes of the New Order administration, a supporter of national development and a person with ability recognised both home and abroad.
Golkar has also said age need not be a factor in deciding on a candidate.
Suharto, 75, has ruled Indonesia since the 1960s.
